content.description: Encopresis is characterized by the repeated passage of feces into inappropriate places (e.g., clothing, floor), whether involuntary or intentional, occurring at least once a month for at least three months. The behavior must occur in a child who is chronologically or developmentally older than 4 years. It may occur with or without constipation and overflow incontinence.
content.diagnostic_criteria: A. Repeated passage of feces into inappropriate places (e.g., clothing, floor), whether involuntary or intentional. B. At least one such event occurs each month for at least three months. C. Chronological age is at least 4 years (or equivalent developmental level). D. The behavior is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., laxatives) or another medical condition except through a mechanism involving constipation.
content.prevalence: Estimated at approximately 1% of 5-year-olds, with decreasing rates in older children. More common in males than females.
content.age_of_onset: Typically diagnosed after age 4; often develops between ages 5 and 7.
content.prognosis: With appropriate treatment, many children achieve full continence. Prognosis is better when constipation is addressed promptly and when behavioral interventions are consistent. Chronic constipation and untreated psychosocial stressors can prolong symptoms.

physiological_mechanisms: In constipation-associated encopresis, chronic stool retention leads to rectal dilation and reduced sensation, decreasing urge to defecate.
Possible altered rectoanal inhibitory reflex sensitivity in chronic cases.
brain_gut_axis: Psychological stress can influence bowel function through autonomic and enteric nervous system pathways.

history: Detailed bowel movement history, including frequency, consistency, and associated symptoms.
History of toilet training, prior continence, and any regression.
physical_exam: Rectal exam for tone, stool presence, and fissures.
investigations: Abdominal X-ray if fecal impaction suspected.
Screening for neurological deficits if indicated.

involuntary_soiling: Staining of underwear with small amounts of stool.
full_bowel_movements: Passage of larger amounts of stool in inappropriate places.

school_age: More likely to present with constipation-related encopresis.

impact_on_life.relationships: May cause embarrassment and social withdrawal.
impact_on_life.school: Teasing or bullying from peers can occur.
impact_on_life.self_esteem: Negative self-image due to soiling incidents.

medical: Laxatives or stool softeners for constipation.
dietary: Increased dietary fiber and fluid intake.
psychological: Address underlying emotional or behavioral issues.

treatment_goals: Improve childâ€™s confidence and participation in social activities.
warning_signs: Sudden onset in a previously toilet-trained child.
Associated weight loss, vomiting, or neurological signs.
real_life_examples: A 6-year-old boy with a history of constipation soils his underwear several times a week despite toilet training.
An 8-year-old girl begins soiling after moving to a new school, with normal bowel habits previously.
content.when_to_seek_help: Seek evaluation if a child older than 4 has persistent soiling, especially with signs of constipation, abdominal pain, or behavioral changes.
missed_diagnosis_factors: Attributing soiling solely to behavioral problems without assessing for constipation.
Failing to perform physical exam or rectal assessment.
overdiagnosis_factors: Diagnosing before age 4 or before toilet training is complete.
